content.text: is designed to identify discrepancies between gas usage reported at the account level and the meter level for a given billing period. It aggregates data from two tables:
. The view calculates the net differences in gas usage (in CCF and Therms) and derives a therm factor for accounts where discrepancies exist.
The complexity of this view is considered medium due to the following factors:
It involves aggregation and grouping operations on two separate tables.
It performs calculations to derive new columns (
It uses a conditional logic with
It joins two subqueries, which adds to the complexity of understanding and maintaining the view.
: The view depends on two tables:
are used to compute totals and factors.
) by subtracting meter values from account values.
is calculated using a conditional division, ensuring no division by zero.
: The view is used to identify and analyze discrepancies between reported gas usage at the account and meter levels, which is crucial for billing accuracy and auditing.
Billing departments can use this view to investigate and resolve discrepancies.
Auditors can use it to ensure data integrity and compliance.
It can be used in reporting tools to provide insights into billing discrepancies.
functions can be resource-intensive, especially if the underlying tables are large.
: The inner join between two aggregated subqueries may impact performance, particularly if indexes are not optimized.
clause filters out rows where there are no discrepancies, which helps in reducing the result set size but may still require scanning large portions of data.
: Ensure that only authorized users have access to this view, as it involves sensitive billing information.
: Consider implementing row-level security if different users should see different subsets of data.
: Log access to this view to monitor who is querying sensitive billing discrepancy data.
: Ensure that the underlying tables have appropriate indexes on
to optimize join and aggregation performance.
: Regularly validate the data in the underlying tables to ensure accuracy and consistency, as discrepancies may arise from data entry errors.

to ensure it aligns with business rules and accurately reflects the intended calculation.
